barriers.description: Not seeing rural-urban areas as complex systems will be a barrier for transformative development.
All rural-urban areas are context specific and not capturing these specifics is a barrier for development.
Systemic transformation can only occur if collaborative and long-term thinking is the starting point.
Might lead to failed collaborations and creates short term and siloed thinking.

leveragePoints.action: Develop a wellbeing model, from an emergent, contextual, rural-urban starting point
leveragePoints.description: Connect all activities towards a long-term systemic vision; create shared sense of urgency and strong coalition of supporters.

leveragePoints.action: Identify local strengths and heritage resources
leveragePoints.description: Connect initiatives to specific context; build motivation and support for transformation.

leveragePoints.action: Make sure to include and listen to all relevant actors in the system
leveragePoints.description: Empower local communities and stakeholders to take ownership of the change process.

leveragePoints.action: Create inventory of drivers of change
leveragePoints.description: Creates understanding of how change happens now and in the future in the area, and how one can influence these changes.
Recognize and celebrate short-term wins to maintain motivation and build momentum for long-term change.
Public bodies as large-scale purchasers can act as anchor institutions in changing markets and behaviours.

leveragePoints.action: Considering and connecting different types of community capital
leveragePoints.description: Financial, political, social, built, natural, cultural, human capital exist in the system; connecting these is essential for transformation.

leveragePoints.action: Learning from others to find pathways forward
leveragePoints.description: Find good examples of innovations from others; adapt good principles, not rigid best practices.
